title: Critérium du Dauphiné 2025 preview: Route, favourites, how to watch and start list
content:
Cyclist
Critérium du Dauphiné 2025 preview: Route, favourites, how to watch and start list

Considered to be the premium Tour de France warm-up race, the Critérium du Dauphiné 2025 will run from the 8th-15th June in central and eastern France. Historically speaking, the Dauphiné is one of the finale litmus tests before the Grand Départ, with Tour favourites choosing the French race as a chance to size up their opposition on similar roads. It’s got a convincing conversion rate, with Bernard Hinault, Bradley Wiggins, Chris Froome and Jonas Vingegaard all claiming the week-long race before tasting Tour de France glory a month later.

The lineup for the 2025 edition is one of the strongest we’ve seen in years. The podium from last year’s Tour de France – Tadej Pogačar, Jonas Vingegaard and Remco Evenepoel – will all be in attendance. This will be their first clash since last year’s Grande Boucle, with just one month until the start of the Tour in Lille. Alongside these three superstars, the startlist includes Carlos Rodríguez, Lenny Martinez, Enric Mas, Florian Lipowitz and Mattias Skjelmose. All of these hopefuls are set to compete at the Tour de France next month.

Critérium du Dauphiné 2025 key information

  • Date: Sunday 8th June-Sunday 15th June
  • Start: Domérat
  • Finish: Val-Cenis
  • Distance: 1201.9km
  • Live TV coverage: TNT Sports, Discovery+, Peacock, SBS, FloBikes, SuperSport
  • 2024 winner: Primož Roglič (Red Bull-Bora-Hansgrohe)

Critérium du Dauphiné 2025 route and stage-by-stage preview

For the second year in a row, the Dauphiné begins in the Allier département. The opening stage features a looped finale, filled with short kickers around the town of Montluçon. From the north-westerly corner of the historic Dauphiné region, the race moves southwards, travelling down to Issoire, which held a Tour de France stage just a couple of years ago. Nearby, Stage 3 will be an emotional one for Romain Bardet, as he starts the day in his hometown of Brioude in the final race of his career before tackling a long and rolling route to Charantonnay.

The following afternoon will offer the race’s only time-trial, with 17km against the clock for the riders this year. There’s a slight bump in the profile, as the riders navigate themselves around Saint-Péray’s wine-making slopes. After the GC pecking order gets a bit of a shake-up, the peloton brushes past Lyon on Stage 5’s change of direction northwards to Mâcon.

Finally, after almost a week of build-up, Stage 6 will send the riders into the Alps, first on a stage that will bring back good memories for Jonas Vingegaard, who decimated the field in a time-trial to the finishing town of Combloux back at the 2023 Tour de France. The day after serves up the toughest mountain challenges of the whole race, with the Col de la Madeleine and the Col de la Croix de Fer en route to the finale at Valmeinier.

As it often does, the 2025 Dauphiné closes off with one final Alpine test right in the south of Savoie with the long drag up to Val-Cenis ski resort. Here the winner will be crowned.

Stage 1: Domérat – Montluçon, 195.8km

The opening stage of the 2025 Critérium du Dauphiné takes the riders on a loop around Montluçon. The stage offers a rolling profile with the chance of a reduced bunch sprint. The opening day of the Dauphiné can’t be second-guessed however. Sometimes, a breakaway can go all the way.

Stage 2: Prémilhat – Issoire, 204.6km

We’re right in the centre of France for Stage 2, which will head around the hilly volcanic core of the nation. There are a few bumps along the way to Issoire, but it shouldn’t be too selective of a profile in all honesty.

Stage 3: Brioude – Charantonnay, 207.2km

Stage 3 will be a big one for Romain Bardet. The Brioude native will start in his hometown, during his final race before retirement.

The profile itself is quite testing, but it’s typical of this region. Breakaways often go well on these kinds of roads, but watch out if it rains, because the tarmac can get particularly slippery in wetter conditions.

Stage 4: Charmes-sur-Rhône – Saint-Péray, 17.4km (ITT)

It’s time to get the ITT legs on for Stage 4’s race against the clock in the Rhône valley. The course will be punctuated by a 1.6km-long climb at 9%, which comes at the halfway point. This should favour the GC riders over the pure time-trialists in theory, but the Dauphiné has been known to throw up a few surprise results against the clock.

For wine aficionados, Saint-Péray used to make a sparkling white wine not too dissimilar to champagne. The bubbles are gone nowadays, but rumour has it that the first wine Napoleon ever drank was from Saint-Péray.

Stage 5: Saint-Priest – Mâcon, 183km

We move back to the north of the region for Stage 5, heading up the Rhône to Mâcon. There’s not much to note here. It’s likely to be a sprint or a breakaway-friendly arrival.

Stage 6: Valserhône – Combloux, 126.7km

Stage 6 enters the Alps at long last. There are a couple of mid-length kickers throughout the stage, but the final 10km will see the first all-out GC battle. The Côte de Domancy is where Vingegaard laid his first crucial blow on Tadej Pogačar during the 2023 Tour de France. It’ll also be the focal point of the 2027 UCI Road World Championships route. So consider this a recon.

That said, the stage doesn’t finish atop the Domancy, it continues to the summit of the Côte de la Fry. That brings the total climbing in the final phase up to 6km at an average gradient of 8%.

Stage 7: Grand-Aigueblanche – Valmeinier 1800, 131.6km

Instead of revisiting Albertville down the road, the Dauphiné has opted to use Grand-Aigueblanche as the start location. Located right at the foot of the Col de la Madeleine, the mountain roads arrive immediately after the flag drop. After that first hors-catégorie climb, we roll straight onto the Col de la Croix de Fer, another HC test.

The final climb of Valemeinier will be fairly unknown to the peloton. Usually, they’d miss the turn off for the ski resort and carry on climbing up the Col du Galibier instead. Otherwise, the 16km-long ramp has been used on several occasions at the lower-tier Tour de Savoie, but never before at the Dauphiné.

Stage 8: Val-d’Arc – Val-Cenis, 133.3km

The final stage is a slow burner. Everything will build up to the final climb to Val-Cenis, right on the border with Italy. That final ascent will be just under 10km in length and at an average gradient of 6.9%. It’s not quite the leg breaker some people may have been hoping for, however the 5km plateau afterwards could shuffle the GC and exacerbate some gaps on the road.

Critérium du Dauphiné 2025 favourites

This year’s Dauphiné will feature the bulk of contenders for the upcoming Tour de France. The two everyone will have their eyes on will, of course, be Tadej Pogačar and Jonas Vingegaard. The Slovenian, who makes his return to racing after a month and a half break, has never won the Dauphiné before, having often skipped the race in favour of the Tour of Slovenia.

The 2023 Dauphiné champion Vingegaard will also be making somewhat of a return to racing. The Dane crashed out of Paris-Nice and subsequently reshuffled his calendar, favouring altitude camps over racing. Now he’s back, and with the support of Sepp Kuss and Wilco Kelderman we’ll get to see Visma-Lease a Bike in their robotic splendour for the first time this summer.

Remco Evenepoel should also be a contender. The Belgian’s stage racing form is patchy, but there’s a good chance that he wins Stage 4’s time-trial in Saint-Péray regardless of whether he sticks around in the GC or not. Otherwise, former Tour contenders Carlos Rodríguez and Enric Mas should be up there, as should Red Bull’s young talent Florian Lipowitz, who will be fast-tracked to the Tour this July, and home favourite Lenny Martinez.

  • ★★★★★: Tadej Pogačar (UAE Team Emirates XRG)
  • ★★★★: Jonas Vingegaard (Visma-Lease a Bike)
  • ★★★: Remco Evenepoel (Soudal-QuickStep), Carlos Rodríguez (Ineos Grenadiers), Mattias Skjelmose (Lidl-Trek), Lenny Martinez (Bahrain Victorious)
  • ★★: Enric Mas (Movistar), Santiago Buitrago (Bahrain Victorious), Florian Lipowitz (Red Bull-Bora-Hansgrohe)
  • ★: Harold Tejada (XDS-Astana), Max Poole (Picnic-PostNL), Felix Gall (Decathlon-AG2R), Paul Seixas (Decathlon-AG2R), Ben Healy (EF Education-EasyPost), Guillaume Martin (Groupama-FDJ)

Critérium du Dauphiné 2025: How to watch

The Critérium du Dauphiné will be shown live on TNT Sports 1 and 3 throughout the week in the UK and Ireland. To watch the race online, you can tune in via Discovery+ from 14:30 BST each day.

Elsewhere, fans in the US can catch the action on Peacock, in Canada it’ll be on FloBikes, in Australia it’s on SBS, in Sub-Saharan Africa it’s on SuperSport, and it’s on all the usual channels throughout Europe.

If the race isn’t being broadcast in your country or you are travelling abroad, a VPN will allow you to hide your device’s location to access content that is normally geo-blocked. One such VPN provider is ExpressVPN, which is well reviewed, helps users to find free-to-watch cycling, and costs start from around £5 per month.

  • Read more: Which countries can watch cycling for free in 2025?
